content.question: Which of the following graphs could depict this situation, where volume, in cubic centimeters, is the independent variable and radius, in centimeters, is the dependent variable?

choices.label: Neither axis shows tick marks or a scale. The x axis is labeled Volume, in cubic centimeters. The y axis is labeled Radius, in centimeters. Moving from left to right: The curve begins on the positive y axis. The curve decreases, sharply at first and then at a lesser and lesser rate. The curve ends just above the positive x axis.

Neither axis shows tick marks or a scale. The x axis is labeled Volume, in cubic centimeters. The y axis is labeled Radius, in centimeters. Moving from left to right: The curve begins at the origin. The curve increases, sharply at first and then at a lesser and lesser rate. The curve ends at the top right of the window in the first quadrant.

Neither axis shows tick marks or a scale. The x axis is labeled Volume, in cubic centimeters. The y axis is labeled Radius, in centimeters. Moving from left to right: The curve begins on the positive y axis just above the origin. The curve increases, nearly horizontal at first and then at a greater and greater rate. The curve ends at the top right of the window in the first quadrant.

Neither axis shows tick marks or a scale. The x axis is labeled Volume, in cubic centimeters. The y axis is labeled Radius, in centimeters. Moving from left to right: The curve begins on the positive y axis. The curve decreases, gradually at first and then at a greater and greater rate. The curve ends at a point just above the positive x axis.

content.answer: Neither axis shows tick marks or a scale. The x axis is labeled Volume, in cubic centimeters. The y axis is labeled Radius, in centimeters. Moving from left to right: The curve begins at the origin. The curve increases, sharply at first and then at a lesser and lesser rate. The curve ends at the top right of the window in the first quadrant.

skill.text: Skill 2.B: Construct equivalent graphical, numerical, analytical, and verbal representations of functions that are useful in a given mathematical or applied context, with and without technology.
